title: Squirrel with a Gun
description:
I was hooked when I got a hold of this little furry powerhouse . The gameplay in Squirrel with a Gun is unlike anything I have played. You are a squirrel, have a gun, and exist within an open-world setting. That itself would draw you in, but it’s the execution that keeps you playing. Dawn of Defiance
You get to run around like this tiny Squirrel with pistols and shotguns. The game lets you go free, combining combat, exploration, and puzzle-solving. I loved how every challenge felt big, given the tiny size of the Squirrel. Getting around human-sized obstacles in and of themselves felt like a game. Were you using gun recoil to launch me across rooftops? Ridiculously fun!
The controls are smooth, and everything balances challenge and approachability well, whether you’re shooting enemies, sneaking past guards, or just messing around in the environment . It feels fresh and exciting every moment.
Combat The first time I saw my Squirrel fly backwards, rebounding from a gun’s recoil into a perfect landing on a ledge, I couldn’t stop laughing. It’s just comedy gold- how physics works in this game. But beneath its goofy premise, combat is strangely thoughtful. You’ve got to think about what weapon to use, how to handle the recoil, and when to sneak or attack head-on.
And the stealth mechanics are natural treats, too. One could find himself going through gardens, hiding behind minuscule objects, plotting the next move- some furry James Bond, if you may. Plus, the variety of weapons adds a ton of fun: from silly overpowered bazookas to tiny pistols, which can barely fit in the Squirrel’s hands, just large enough to be absurd. Each weapon feels different, and experimenting with them is almost a game
